20110127141741.000|20110127141744.000|TR0|be on.
20110127141744.000|20110127141746.000|TR0|
20110127141746.000|20110127141749.000|TR0|PHILLIPS:  All right, so, here's what we 
20110127141749.000|20110127141752.000|TR0|are wondering.  Well, maybe I -- just let 
20110127141752.000|20110127141754.000|TR0|me just get your take.  What the heck is 
20110127141754.000|20110127141757.000|TR0|going on with our weather?  It -- we're 
20110127141757.000|20110127141800.000|TR0|seeing winters like we've never seen.  We 
20110127141800.000|20110127141802.000|TR0|saw a summer like we've never seen.  Are 
20110127141802.000|20110127141805.000|TR0|we going to -- is it going to keep getting 
20110127141805.000|20110127141807.000|TR0|worse?  Is this going to be the trend from 
20110127141807.000|20110127141810.000|TR0|this day forward?
20110127141810.000|20110127141813.000|TR0|
20110127141813.000|20110127141815.000|TR0|KAKU:  Perhaps.  Common sense says that 
20110127141815.000|20110127141818.000|TR0|it's freezing weather which drives monster 
20110127141818.000|20110127141821.000|TR0|snowstorms.  The common sense is wrong.  
20110127141821.000|20110127141823.000|TR0|When arctic air from Canada hits moist air 
20110127141823.000|20110127141826.000|TR0|from the Gulf of Mexico, it's the 
20110127141826.000|20110127141828.000|TR0|moisture, which then freezes, causing 
20110127141828.000|20110127141831.000|TR0|monster snowstorms.
20110127141831.000|20110127141834.000|TR0|
20110127141834.000|20110127141836.000|TR0|So if you take ice cubes, if you make ice 
20110127141836.000|20110127141839.000|TR0|cubes, the amount of water you put in your 
20110127141839.000|20110127141842.000|TR0|refrigerator determines the amount of ice 
20110127141842.000|20110127141844.000|TR0|cubes you get, not the temperature of the 
20110127141844.000|20110127141847.000|TR0|refrigerator.
20110127141847.000|20110127141849.000|TR0|
20110127141849.000|20110127141852.000|TR0|So, the earth is heating up.  So there is 
20110127141852.000|20110127141855.000|TR0|one theory that says that the heating of 
20110127141855.000|20110127141857.000|TR0|the earth creates more moisture in the 
20110127141857.000|20110127141900.000|TR0|air, which then collides with arctic ice 
20110127141900.000|20110127141903.000|TR0|-- winds to create monster snowstorms. 
20110127141903.000|20110127141905.000|TR0|Violating common sense.
20110127141905.000|20110127141908.000|TR0|
20110127141908.000|20110127141911.000|TR0|PHILLIPS:  OK.  Well, I thought the 
20110127141911.000|20110127141913.000|TR0|theories out there -- OK, what's causing 
20110127141913.000|20110127141916.000|TR0|all of this?  There's two theories out 
20110127141916.000|20110127141918.000|TR0|there, right?  Random fluctuation is one.  
20110127141918.000|20110127141921.000|TR0|And then, of course, global warming.  
20110127141921.000|20110127141924.000|TR0|What's your take?
20110127141924.000|20110127141926.000|TR0|
20110127141926.000|20110127141929.000|TR0|KAKU:  Yes, random fluctuations could be 
20110127141929.000|20110127141932.000|TR0|it.  For example, last year, we had El 
20110127141932.000|20110127141934.000|TR0|Nino, another fluctuation.
20110127141934.000|20110127141937.000|TR0|
20110127141937.000|20110127141939.000|TR0|But this current trend is consistent, 
20110127141939.000|20110127141942.000|TR0|also, with global warming.  You see, 
20110127141942.000|20110127141945.000|TR0|global warming does not mean uniform 
20110127141945.000|20110127141947.000|TR0|warming of the earth.  It means swings.  
20110127141947.000|20110127141950.000|TR0|Very violent swings.  I was in Brazil last 
20110127141950.000|20110127141953.000|TR0|week, where there's gigantic mudslides, 
20110127141953.000|20110127141955.000|TR0|the largest in a generation, caused by 
20110127141955.000|20110127141958.000|TR0|flooding.  Flooding, in turn, is caused by 
20110127141958.000|20110127142000.000|TR0|more moisture in the air.
20110127142000.000|20110127142003.000|TR0|
20110127142003.000|20110127142006.000|TR0|So, droughts can happen simultaneously 
20110127142006.000|20110127142008.000|TR0|with flooding, monster snowstorms could 
20110127142008.000|20110127142011.000|TR0|happen simultaneously with heat spells.  
20110127142011.000|20110127142014.000|TR0|So, it's not a uniform heating of the 
20110127142014.000|20110127142016.000|TR0|earth.  But that's one theory.  PHILLIPS:  
20110127142016.000|20110127142019.000|TR0|Interesting.  Because, you know, if you 
20110127142019.000|20110127142022.000|TR0|look at here in the United States, we had 
20110127142022.000|20110127142024.000|TR0|this Atlanta snow that we haven't seen in 
20110127142024.000|20110127142027.000|TR0|decades, right?  It literally shut us

20110127142048.000|20110127142050.000|TR0|lost their lives.  So, you tend to wonder, 
20110127142050.000|20110127142053.000|TR0|OK, what is happening globally here?   And

20110127142104.000|20110127142106.000|TR0|
20110127142106.000|20110127142109.000|TR0|KAKU:  Right.  There's no smoking gun as 
20110127142109.000|20110127142112.000|TR0|to the cause.  However, 2005 and last year 
20110127142112.000|20110127142114.000|TR0|went down as the hottest years ever 
20110127142114.000|20110127142117.000|TR0|recorded in science since 1880, when 
20110127142117.000|20110127142119.000|TR0|records were first kept.  So it's 
20110127142119.000|20110127142122.000|TR0|consistent, consistent with global 
20110127142122.000|20110127142125.000|TR0|warming, which means more swings in the 
20110127142125.000|20110127142127.000|TR0|weather, which means more hurricanes, more 
20110127142127.000|20110127142130.000|TR0|droughts, as well as more monster storms.  
20110127142130.000|20110127142133.000|TR0|And we're going to have to get used to it.
20110127142133.000|20110127142135.000|TR0|
20110127142135.000|20110127142138.000|TR0|PHILLIPS;  And we're going to be in for a

20110127142143.000|20110127142146.000|TR0|KAKU:  Probably, right.  The weather is 
20110127142146.000|20110127142148.000|TR0|changing.  There's no debate about that.  
20110127142148.000|20110127142151.000|TR0|The debate is of whether or not human 
20110127142151.000|20110127142154.000|TR0|activity is driving it.  But even the 
20110127142154.000|20110127142156.000|TR0|critics of global warming admit that yes, 
20110127142156.000|20110127142159.000|TR0|the earth is warming, which means more
